---
title: "Mental health outcomes DataSchema"
output: html_document
---
```{r, echo=TRUE}
library(car)
library(dplyr)
library(epiDisplay)
library(scales)
library(sjmisc)
library(tidyverse)

# Connecting with Opal data server
## Login to server and assign study data
# Load Opal R library
library(opal)
# Create an Opal object with the login information
erasmus_opal <- opal.login()
# Login to Opal server and assign the content of the HAPIEE table(s) to your RStudio environment
# HAPIEE wave 1
opal.assign.table.tibble(erasmus_opal, 'HAPIEE_W1','HAPIEE.HAPIEE_W1', variables = list('country','p54g','p54l','p54n','p54o','p54s','p54a','p54c','p54i','p54m','p54h','p54k','p54p','p54r','p54b','p54d','p54e','p54f','p54j','p54q','p54t','r9c','r9e','r9f','r9i','r9l','r9o','r9q','r9r','r9a','r9g','r9h','r9k','r9n','r9d','r9s','r9b','r9m','r9j','r9p','cog1','cog2','cog3','cog12','cog7','cog8','cog9','cog10'))
HAPIEE_W1 <- opal.execute(erasmus_opal, 'HAPIEE_W1')

#HAPIEE wave 2
opal.assign.table.tibble(erasmus_opal, 'HAPIEE_W2','HAPIEE.HAPIEE_W2', variables = list('country','w2p54g','w2p54k','w2p54p','w2p54s','w2p54t','w2p54o','w2p54f','w2p54n','w2p54l','w2p54r','w2r9b','w2r9e','w2r9f','w2r9i','w2r9j','w2r9n','w2r9r','w2r9d','w2r9k','w2r9o','w2r9a','w2r9s','w2cog1','w2cog2','w2cog3','w2cog12','w2cog7','w2cog8','w2cog9','w2cog10'))
HAPIEE_W2 <- opal.execute(erasmus_opal, 'HAPIEE_W2')

#HAPIEE postal 2009
opal.assign.table.tibble(erasmus_opal, 'HAPIEE_postal2009','HAPIEE.HAPIEE_postal2009', variables = list('country','h2p54g','h2p54n','h2p54p','h2p54s','h2p54t','h2p54k','h2p54o','h2p54r','h2p54f','h2p54l'))
HAPIEE_postal2009 <- opal.execute(erasmus_opal, 'HAPIEE_postal2009')

#HAPIEE postal 2012
opal.assign.table.tibble(erasmus_opal, 'HAPIEE_postal2012','HAPIEE.HAPIEE_postal2012', variables = list('country','h3p54f','h3p54g','h3p54k','h3p54n','h3p54r','h3p54p','h3p54t','h3p54o','h3p54l','h3p54s'))
HAPIEE_postal2012 <- opal.execute(erasmus_opal, 'HAPIEE_postal2012')
```
## Select country-specific sample
```{r,echo=FALSE}
HAPIEE_W1 <- subset(HAPIEE_W1, HAPIEE_W1$country==2)
HAPIEE_W2 <- subset(HAPIEE_W2, HAPIEE_W2$country==2)
HAPIEE_postal2009 <- subset(HAPIEE_postal2009, HAPIEE_postal2009$country==2)
HAPIEE_postal2012 <- subset(HAPIEE_postal2012, HAPIEE_postal2012$country==2)
```
## Assign participant id as first column of your harmonized dataframes
```{r,echo=FALSE}
mho_HAPIEE_RU_0 <- data.frame(id = HAPIEE_W1$id)
mho_HAPIEE_RU_1 <- data.frame(id = HAPIEE_W2$id)
mho_HAPIEE_RU_2 <- data.frame(id = HAPIEE_postal2009$id)
mho_HAPIEE_RU_3 <- data.frame(id = HAPIEE_postal2012$id)

# When you are done with your work, logout of Opal server
opal.logout(erasmus_opal)

```

# Cognitive functioning subdomain

### **Variable label**:  Immediate word recall 
**Variable name**:  cog_imm_rscale_0  
**Variable description**:  Rescaled value (ranging from 0 to 10) of the total number of words immediately recalled during a test of verbal memory. If the test is performed more than once, data are based on the first trial.  
**Value type**:  integer    
**Variable unit**:  words  
**Category coding**:  N/A 

**Harmonization status**: complete     
**Harmonization comment**: Immediate word recall of 10 common two syllable words was measured in HAPIEE. As three trials of immediate word recall were assessed, data from the first trial were used. The number of words (0-10) immediately recalled were used as provided by the HAPIEE study.               
**R script**:  
```{r, echo=TRUE}
mho_HAPIEE_RU_0$cog_imm_rscale_0 <- HAPIEE_W1$cog1

```

### **Variable label**:  Immediate word recall 
**Variable name**:  cog_imm_rscale_1

**Value type**:  integer    
**Variable unit**:  words  
**Category coding**:  N/A 

**Harmonization status**: complete    
**Harmonization comment**: Immediate word recall of 10 common two syllable words was measured in HAPIEE. As three trials of immediate word recall were assessed, data from the first trial were used. The number of words (0-10) immediately recalled were used as provided by the HAPIEE study.       
**R script**:

mho_HAPIEE_RU_1$cog_imm_rscale_1 <- HAPIEE_W2$w2cog1

### **Variable label**:  Low immediate word recall     
**Variable name**:  cog_imm_low_0    
**Variable description**:  Indicator of whether the participant has low immediate word recall using a median split on the total (rescaled) number of words immediately recalled. If the test is performed more than once, data are based on the first trial.   
**Value type**:  integer  
**Variable unit**:  N/A   
**Category coding**:  

**Code** | **Category Label**  
------------- | -------------  
0 |   High immediate word recall  
1 |   Low immediate word recall

**Harmonization status**: complete    
**Harmonization comment**: This was based on the number of words (0-10) immediately recalled from the first trial in HAPIEE.         
**R script**:  
```{r, echo=TRUE}
mho_HAPIEE_RU_0$cog_imm_low_0 <- as.integer(dicho(mho_HAPIEE_RU_0$cog_imm_rscale_0, dich.by = "median", as.num = FALSE, var.label = NULL, val.labels = NULL, append = FALSE, suffix = NULL))

mho_HAPIEE_RU_0$cog_imm_low_0 <- as.integer(car::recode(mho_HAPIEE_RU_0$cog_imm_low_0, "2=0"))

```

### **Variable label**:  Processing speed  
**Variable name**:  cog_proc_std_0  
**Variable description**:  Standardised value (z-score) of the total number of items recalled correctly in a processing speed task. If the test is performed more than once, data are based on the first trial.    
**Value type**:  numeric    
**Variable unit**: items  
**Category coding**:  N/A  

**Harmonization status**: complete       
**Harmonization comment**: Processing speed was measured with a letter search task in HAPIEE. Using an A4 grid consisting of 780 random letters arranged in rows and columns, participants were asked to cross out as many of the letters 'p' and 'w' in 1 minute. The total score of the number of letters correctly crossed out (0-65) was calculated by the HAPIEE study, which was transformed to a z-score.      
**R script**:  
```{r, echo=TRUE}
mho_HAPIEE_RU_0$cog_proc_std_0 <- scale(HAPIEE_W1$cog10)

```

# Depression subdomain

### **Variable label**:  Depressive symptom severity tertiles    
**Variable name**:  psy_dep_tertile_0  
**Variable description**:  Indicator of whether the participant has low, medium or high severity of depressive symptoms measured by tertiles of the scale-specific depressive symptom score.     
**Value type**:  integer   
**Variable unit**:  N/A  
**Category coding**:  

**Code** | **Category Label**  
------------- | -------------  
0 |   Low severity tertile of depressive symptoms
1 |   Medium severity tertile of depressive symptoms
2 |   High severity tertile of depressive symptoms 

**Harmonization status**: complete     
**Harmonization comment**: The CES-D 20 depression scores (0-60) were grouped into population-specific tertiles for the Russian HAPIEE cohort: low (0-8), medium (9-12), and high (13-60). Scores were calculate for participants with data on least 16 items (out of a possible 20). If 1 or more items were missing, scores on the completed items were summed and divided by the number of items completed, then multiplied by 20. If participants missed 5 or more items, scores were not calculated and coded as missing. Items comprising the *Center for Epidemiological Studies Depression Scale, 20 item version*, are listed below.  
*Below is a list of the ways you might have felt or behaved. Please tell me how often you have felt this way during the past week:*
1. I was bothered by things that usually don't bother me.  
2. I did not feel like eating; my appetite was poor.  
3. I felt that I could not shake off the blues even with help from my family or friends.  
4. I felt that I was just as good as other people.  
5. I had trouble keeping my mind on what I was doing.  
6. I felt depressed.  
7. I felt that everything I did was an effort.  
8. I felt hopeful about the future.  
9. I thought my life had been a failure.  
10. I felt fearful.  
11. My sleep was restless.  
12. I was happy.  
13. I talked less than usual.  
14. I felt lonely.  
15. People were unfriendly.  
16. I enjoyed life.  
17. I had crying spells.  
18. I felt sad.  
19. I felt that people dislike me.  
20. I could not get "going".  
Responses ranged from 'less than 1 day' (0), '1-2 days' (1), '3-4 days' (2), '5-7 days' (3).    

**R script**:  
As responses were coded from 'rarely or never' (1) to 'mostly or always,' (4) in HAPIEE, these were recoded to a 0-3 response scale.    
```{r, echo=TRUE}
HAPIEE_W1$p54a_i <- as.integer(HAPIEE_W1$p54a - 1) 
HAPIEE_W1$p54b_i <- as.integer(HAPIEE_W1$p54b - 1) 
HAPIEE_W1$p54c_i <- as.integer(HAPIEE_W1$p54c - 1) 
HAPIEE_W1$p54d_i <- as.integer(HAPIEE_W1$p54d - 1) 
HAPIEE_W1$p54e_i <- as.integer(HAPIEE_W1$p54e - 1) 
HAPIEE_W1$p54f_i <- as.integer(HAPIEE_W1$p54f - 1) 
HAPIEE_W1$p54g_i <- as.integer(HAPIEE_W1$p54g - 1) 
HAPIEE_W1$p54h_i <- as.integer(HAPIEE_W1$p54h - 1)   
HAPIEE_W1$p54i_i <- as.integer(HAPIEE_W1$p54i - 1) 
HAPIEE_W1$p54j_i <- as.integer(HAPIEE_W1$p54j - 1) 
HAPIEE_W1$p54k_i <- as.integer(HAPIEE_W1$p54k - 1) 
HAPIEE_W1$p54l_i <- as.integer(HAPIEE_W1$p54l - 1)
HAPIEE_W1$p54m_i <- as.integer(HAPIEE_W1$p54m - 1)

Scores were calculate for participants with data on least 8 items (out of a possible 10). If 1 or 2 items were missing, scores on the completed items were summed and divided by the number of items completed, then multiplied by 10. If participants missed 3 or more items, scores were not calculated and coded as missing. 4. I was happy.  
5. I felt lonely.  
6. People were unfriendly.  
7. I enjoyed life.  
8. I felt sad.  
9. I felt that people dislike me.  
10. I could not get "going".  
Responses options were 'yes' (1) or 'no' (0).

# Quality of life subdomain

### **Variable label**:  Quality of life tertiles  
**Variable name**:  psy_qol_tertile_0  
**Variable description**:  Indicator of whether the participant has high, medium or low levels of quality of life measured by tertiles of the scale-specific quality of life score.  
**Value type**:  integer  
**Variable unit**:  N/A  
**Category coding**:  

**Code** | **Category Label**  
------------- | -------------  
0 | High levels of quality of life  
1 | Medium levels of quality of life
2 | Low levels of quality of life 

**Harmonization status**: complete    
**Harmonization comment**: The CASP-19 quality of life scores (0-57) in HAPIEE were grouped into population-specific tertiles for the Russian HAPIEE cohort: low (0-19), medium (20-27), and high (28-57). Scores were calculate for participants with data on least 16 items (out of a possible 19). If 1 or more items were missing, scores on the completed items were summed and divided by the number of items completed, then multiplied by 19. If participants missed 4 or more items, scores were not calculated and coded as missing. Items comprising the *Control, Autonomy, Satisfaction and Pleasure Scale, 19 item version*, are listed below.    
1. My age prevents me from doing the things I would like to do.   
2. I feel that what happens to me is out of my control.    
3. I feel free to plan for the future.    
4. I feel left out of things.    
5. I can do the things I want to do.  
6. Family responsibilities prevent me from doing what I want to do.  
7. I feel that I can please myself what I do.    
8. My health stops me from doing the things I want to do.  
9. Shortage of money stops me from doing the things I want to do.  
10. I look forward to each day.  
11. I feel that my life has meaning.  
12. I enjoy the things that I do.  
13. I enjoy being in the company of others.  
14. On balance, I look back on my life with a sense of happiness.  
15. I feel full of energy these days.  
16. I choose to do things that I have never done before.  
17. I feel satisfied with the way my life has turned out.  
18. I feel that life is full of opportunities.  
19. I feel that the future looks good for me.  
**Responses ranged from 'often' (0), 'sometimes' (1), 'not often' (2), 'never' (3).      
   
**R script**:  
As responses were coded from 'often' (1) to 'never' (4) in HAPIEE, these were recoded to a 0-3 response scale.  
```{r, echo=TRUE}
HAPIEE_W1$r9a_i <- car::recode(HAPIEE_W1$r9a, "1=0; 2=1; 3=2; 4=3")
HAPIEE_W1$r9b_i <- car::recode(HAPIEE_W1$r9b, "1=0; 2=1; 3=2; 4=3")
HAPIEE_W1$r9c_i <- car::recode(HAPIEE_W1$r9c, "1=0; 2=1; 3=2; 4=3")

HAPIEE_W1$r9n_i <- car::recode(HAPIEE_W1$r9n, "1=0; 2=1; 3=2; 4=3")
HAPIEE_W1$r9o_i <- car::recode(HAPIEE_W1$r9o, "1=0; 2=1; 3=2; 4=3")

Items responses for items 1, 2, 4, 6, 8 and 9 were reverse coded.

Quality of life scores and tertiles were then calculated as follows.  
```{r, echo=TRUE}
HAPIEE_W1$qolnmiss <- apply(HAPIEE_W1[,72:90], MARGIN = 1, FUN = function(x) sum(is.na(x)))

HAPIEE_W1$psy_qol_score_0 <- apply(HAPIEE_W1[,72:90], MARGIN = 1, FUN = function(x) sum(x, na.rm = TRUE))

HAPIEE_W1$psy_qol_score_0[which(HAPIEE_W1$qolnmiss == 3)] <- (HAPIEE_W1$psy_qol_score_0[which(HAPIEE_W1$qolnmiss== 3)]/16)*19
HAPIEE_W1$psy_qol_score_0[which(HAPIEE_W1$qolnmiss == 2)] <- (HAPIEE_W1$psy_qol_score_0[which(HAPIEE_W1$qolnmiss == 2)]/17)*19 
HAPIEE_W1$psy_qol_score_0[which(HAPIEE_W1$qolnmiss == 1)] <- (HAPIEE_W1$psy_qol_score_0[which(HAPIEE_W1$qolnmiss == 1)]/18)*19

HAPIEE_W1$psy_qol_score_0[which(HAPIEE_W1$qolnmiss >= 4)] <- NA_integer_

HAPIEE_W1$psy_qol_score_0 <- round(HAPIEE_W1$psy_qol_score_0)

mho_HAPIEE_RU_0$psy_qol_tertile_0 <- as.integer(car::recode(HAPIEE_W1$psy_qol_score_0, "0:19=0; 20:27=1; 28:57=2"))

```
